comments: This sequence assumes prime(0) = 1.Heuristically, we should expect a(n) -> infinity as n -> infinity, i.e. for any k there should be only finitely many terms <= k. It seems likely that 3 is the only n for which a(n) = 2.  There are at least 14 occurrences of a(n) = 3, including 1, 4, 6, 8, 21, 29, 44, 84, 191, 378, 13006, 39420, 62947, 78156. - _Robert Israel_, Aug 14 2015
links: Harvey P. Dale and Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000(1..1000 from Harvey P. Dale)
maple: Primes:= select(isprime,[2,(2*i+1 $ i=1..1000)]):3, seq(max(numtheory:-factorset(Primes[i]*Primes[i+1]+1)), i=1..nops(Primes)-1); # _Robert Israel_, Aug 14 2015
author: _Clark Kimberling_
